options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: The history of colonial America

title: The Gauntlet | Think Like A Coder, Ep 8

multiple-choice.question: What is the nature of the deadly series of conveyors that wind underneath Huxenborg?

options.label: B
options.text: B: A series of luminous conveyors that split into multiple paths

options.label: C
options.text: A network of tunnels with no clear path

options.label: D
options.text: A series of loops that eventually lead to destruction

options.text: The ability to produce slightly smaller versions of himself

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to communicate with robots

multiple-choice.question: What is recursion, as described in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of loop that repeats a set of instructions

options.label: B
options.text: A set of instructions that refers back to itself

options.label: C
options.text: A way of solving problems that involves self-similarity

multiple-choice.question: What is the base case of the recursion in the problem of finding the safe path?

options.label: B
options.text: When Hedge has produced multiple copies of himself

options.label: C
options.text: When Hedge has reached an intersection

options.label: D
options.text: When Hedge has heard a message over the radio

multiple-choice.question: What instructions should each version of Hedge follow to find the safe path?

options.label: A
options.text: 1. If you've reached the artifact, radio to your parent. 2. When you reach an intersection, move off the conveyor and send new copies down the left and right paths. 3. If you hear anything over the radio, you should radio to your parent and repeat everything you just heard.

options.label: B
options.text: 1. If you've reached the artifact, radio to your parent whether you got there by going left or right. 2. When you reach an intersection, move off the conveyor and send new copies down the left and right paths. 3. If you hear anything over the radio, you should radio to your parent whether you got to your spot by going left or right, then repeat everything you just heard.

options.label: C
options.text: 1. If you've reached the artifact, radio to your parent. 2. When you reach an intersection, move off the conveyor and send new copies down the left and right paths. 3. If you hear anything over the radio, you should radio to your parent.

options.label: D
options.text: 1. If you've reached the artifact, radio to your parent whether you got there by going left or right. 2. When you reach an intersection, move off the conveyor and send new copies down the left and right paths. 3. If you hear anything over the radio, you should radio to your parent.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the Pathfinder action?

options.label: A
options.text: To find the safe path to the artifact

options.label: B
options.text: To communicate with other versions of Hedge

options.label: C
options.text: To repeat instructions to other versions of Hedge

options.label: D
options.text: To solve the problem of recursion

options.label: B

options.label: A
options.text: To use a loop to repeat the instructions

options.label: B

options.text: To use a set of instructions that refers back to itself

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: To solve the problem of recursion

title: The importance of setting in a story

multiple-choice.question: What is the narrator's initial reaction to the book they finished reading?

options.label: A
options.text: They were disappointed with the plot.

options.label: B
options.text: They were impressed with the characters.

options.label: C
options.text: They were confused about the setting.

options.label: D
options.text: They were bored with the story.

multiple-choice.question: What is the narrator's opinion about the setting in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: It's the most important element in a story.

options.label: C
options.text: It can reveal conflicts and plots.

options.label: D
options.text: It's not necessary in a story.

multiple-choice.question: What can be inferred about Todd's situation when he clenched his jaw and was sweating?

options.label: A
options.text: He was running for first place in a race.

options.label: B
options.text: He's sitting in class and stressed.

options.label: C
options.text: He's on a ship and afraid.

options.label: D
options.text: He's on a hike and tired.

multiple-choice.question: What is the narrator's opinion about the author's choice of setting in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: The author chooses a random place and puts their story there.

options.label: B
options.text: The author chooses a setting that informs the mood and theme.

options.label: C
options.text: The author doesn't think about the setting at all.

options.label: D
options.text: The author only chooses a setting that is easy to describe.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the setting in a story, according to the narrator?

options.label: C
options.text: To create a mood and theme.

multiple-choice.question: What is the narrator's opinion about the importance of setting in a story?

options.label: B
options.text: It's only important for the plot.

options.label: C
options.text: It's only important for the characters.

options.label: D
options.text: It's very important and should be chosen carefully.

multiple-choice.question: What is the narrator's opinion about the relationship between setting and mood?

options.label: D
options.text: They are both created by the author.

multiple-choice.question: What is the narrator's opinion about the relationship between setting and theme?

options.label: D
options.text: They are both created by the author.

multiple-choice.question: What is the narrator's opinion about the importance of setting in a story, compared to other elements?

options.label: B
options.text: It's less important than plot and characters.

options.label: C
options.text: It's as important as plot and characters.

options.label: D
options.text: It's more important than plot and characters and theme.

multiple-choice.question: What is the narrator's opinion about the relationship between setting and plot?

options.label: D
options.text: They are both created by the author.
